criteria: Understanding of the Definition of a Drug
Ability to Differentiate Drugs from Other Substances
Understanding of the Impact of Drugs on the Body and Brain
descriptions: The student does not demonstrate an understanding of what constitutes a drug.
The student shows minimal understanding, with significant misconceptions about what a drug is.
The student identifies a drug as a substance, but does not mention its effect on the body or brain.
The student identifies a drug and mentions it affects the body, but not the brain, or vice versa.
The student correctly identifies that a drug is a chemical that changes either the body or the brain.
The student accurately defines a drug as a chemical that changes how both the body and brain work, providing examples.
The student cannot differentiate drugs from other substances like food or water.
The student struggles to differentiate drugs, often confusing them with other types of substances.
The student can somewhat differentiate, but provides inaccurate reasons.
The student identifies some differences between drugs and other substances, but the explanation lacks clarity.
The student clearly differentiates drugs from other substances, providing a basic explanation.
The student clearly and accurately differentiates drugs from other substances, explaining the unique chemical properties and effects that define a drug.
The student shows no understanding of how drugs impact the body and/or brain.
The student demonstrates very limited understanding, with significant inaccuracies.
The student acknowledges that drugs have an impact but cannot explain how or why.
The student provides a vague or incomplete explanation of the impacts of drugs on the body and/or brain.
The student describes the impact of drugs on either the body or brain with some accuracy.
The student comprehensively explains the impacts of drugs on both the body and brain, including specific examples of these impacts.
